physical_examinations.vital_signs: Serum creatinine: 94 mmol/L; Uric acid: 0.46 mmol/L; Magnesium: 0.79 mmol/L; Hemoglobin A1c: 39 mmol/mol; eGFR: 45 ml/min per 1.73 m²; Endogenous creatinine clearance: approximately 80 ml/min.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Renal ultrasound demonstrated multiple cortical as well as parapelvine cysts in both kidneys; the combination of diabetes at a young age and renal cysts was suggestive of HNF1 b-associated disease.
Congenital solitary kidney and multiple small cortical cysts were reported on repeated ultrasonography; elevated liver enzymes were noted.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: The patient subsequently developed gout at age 32 years and diabetes mellitus, with a mildly progressive CKD at age 40 years.

physical_examinations.vital_signs: Magnesium: 0.43 mmol/L; Potassium: 3.5 mmol/L; eGFR: 44 ml/min per 1.73 m²; Fractional excretion of magnesium: 12%; Urine calcium concentration: <0.5 mmol/L.
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Chronic electrolyte disturbances, specifically hypomagnesemia and tendency for hypokalemia; renal ultrasound showed two small kidneys with multiple cysts.
Refractory hypomagnesemia attributed to cisplatin-based chemotherapy; chronic renal insufficiency was present without proteinuria; diabetes diagnosed at age 24 years.
Aplasia of the right kidney with some small cortical cysts in the left solitary kidney; suffered from gout.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Twelve years after presentation, confirmed a heterozygous full deletion of the HNF1B gene; stable renal function at approximately 74 ml/min.
